title: After being stuck in Silver for over a year, I have found the secret to climbing.
body: In the last two or three weeks, I have gone from Silver 3 to Gold 2. How did I do it? Very simple. It's not some secret mechanical outplay trick or anything like that. Here it is: React to situations logically, not emotionally. I'm serious. This simple trick has won me eighteen out of the last twenty games. If your bot lane dies, don't think "Wow, they're bad." think, "Okay, the enemy team is probably going to try to take dragon now. I should attempt a steal." This game is so. Much. Easier.

replies.body:
As a support main for a long af time: the secret is to play *in relation* to how others play, not *according* to how others play.

You have your own form of style, and your team has theirs. Instead of attempting to dictate how another person plays, instead figure out how to use your own unique talents to supplement it. For example, I prefer enchanter-based supports (specifically Nami and Lulu) but also like to be a bit aggressive, as sitting and doing nothing all game just feels boring to me. If my laner is also aggressive, great! We just pubstomp the enemy through our overwhelming force the moment one of us lands a catch. If they're more passive, I take more of a zoning role: attempting to simply poke at them without a full commitment instead of going full-auto aggressive, and saving my crowd control for a moment where we *must* fight, since I know my landing it in most other situations is probably going to be a waste of my mana and cooldowns.

If our jungler is gank-tastic, awesome! I'll rush a sweeper asap and focus on keeping all the paths clear whenever I get a chance. If he's more focused on another lane, or farm heavy, I'll focus far more on keeping our own wards up, and trying to keep vision on the nearest entries to our jungle to try and spot invasions.

Not only does "you suck noob, go in!" never get you anywhere but the banlists, it's actually not accurate in most cases: people play the game differently, and part of the challenge is to play your game in a way that doesn't suck for everyone else.

Yah I  know what you mean, but as top it is not always that simple.  Even if I am pushed up, the way minions move now, I can't really just roam to dragon without half of my tower being taken.  Maybe if I have TP or something, but also we don't have an adc so I could actually die too if my jungler doesn't come as well.    I know you are just pointing out one situation that might not apply to top as much but my point is its not always that simple and usually roaming with a team mate is down means you are going to take some sort of loss on an objective.

The key to top lane is in how efficiently you can farm without being destroyed. As Doge said, if you push to tower, go try and place deep wards for your jungler (or you) to invade more safely. Take Scuttle. Take enemy camps. Take herald if possible. Take, take, take. And give as little as possible. Imho, teleport ganks should only be done if you're planning on losing your tower anyway, in exchange for multiple kills bot, bot tower, and dragon (make them pay for your tower by taking from them far more than what you give)

If the jungler is the shotcaller of your team, and the support is the overwatch of your team, then you as top would be considered more of the backbone of your team. So your job is not necessarily to drive the other team into the ground, more than it is to keep your team standing, even if you take a large hit, by being the most consistent and persistent nuisance possible to the enemy team. If that means you splitpush and take objectives while your team 4v5s, that's how you do it. If it means you group and peel, that's strong too.

But early game especially, your goal is to simply live, farm heavily, and not give up anything for free. Not necessarily to crush the enemy.

I actually have found that what is more important is the 3rd person rule that me and my friends throw around, sorta a joke but not.  Basically, you need 3 people on  your team to not be crap to win.  If you have 3 bad team mates that are feeding you lose (or at least it is really hard to overcome that) and vice versa.

I used to go by that rule a lot too. It has its merits.

But lately, I've started to kind of realize that morale plays a big factor in winning/losing a game. If your bot lane is getting destroyed, for instance, everyone is probably cringing at the state of their lane. For the jungle main of an OP, that usually is a sign that he needs to try and turn the tables on the map somewhere, as the jungler. Be that by snowballing you or mid, or be that by coming down and ganking bot to oblivion to try and turn the lane around, there's no "right" way to handle it, necessarily...or maybe it's easier to say it'll depend on exactly how its going down.

What you can do at top to combat this comes down to 3 things, generally:

- Push in and help secure herald/the whole top side of map (your usual thing, only full-tryhard and taken to an extreme)
- Try a bunch of ganks with your jungler (roam mid/tp gank bot and hope to take kills/tower/drag)
- If it's just that your bot lane is countered, you can attempt a lane swap if you and them are confident it'll help.

Issue with lane-swapping is that Riot's positional ranking system is boning that sort of strategy right now as far as how LP works. >.>
Hopefully they change that soon.

No. It's a probable loss.

And you see that's all it is about. Probabilities. If you have a small chance to still win a game, go for it, because every 5 or 6 games in which you had this small chance to win, you actually do it and win. And these small percentages adds up to a solid 55% winrate overall and that's how you climb.

A losing bot lane is a losing bot lane. There's 3 other people. A hypercarry mid can easily do the same as a hypercarry top. A beefy, unkillable top with proper mid and jungle help is arguably *stronger* than a hypercarry top.

The game is not lost the moment one lane fails.

I'd also say champion choice is one of the biggest factors as to why people are hardstuck Silver/Bronze/Iron.

Why play champions that require near perfect positioning or mechanics when you can play someone like Garen or Sona? Sure, you might like them, but you're already setting yourself up to fail if you choose one of the hardest champions in the game to play only at an average level. 

Also champion pool is a big one. Limit yourself to around 3-5 champions in your main role, with maybe 1-2 (or any broken meta champ that can't do THAT badly, you'll rarely get your secondary role anyway) in your off role. It's great to be a jack of all trades, but also make sure you're a master of one.

Another thing to add, never do things without thinking about the bigger picture. 
For example, you might need some cs, and bot has a big juicy wave pushed up to the turret. 
Your team is setting up for Baron. 
Weigh the consequences; Baron, or 20 cs? 

If the enemy has three bot, do you choose to do Baron, or keep farming?

Do you really need to follow those four other people to clear one super minion wave?

Is suiciding to take down enemy ADC worth it, or should you be killing that 14/2 Kha instead to prevent your own ADC from dying?

If the enemy jungler is top, and enemy mid laner is pushed up to their turret, do you really need a ward in your bot lane river bush?

And remember to never waste time typing to argue with a toxic player.
